org.eng.aisp.dataset

Class MetaData

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.eng.util.AbstractReferenceShuffleIterable<IReferencedSoundSpec,ISoundReferenceSet>
      • org.eng.aisp.dataset.AbstractSoundReferenceSet
        • org.eng.aisp.dataset.MetaData
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterable<IReferencedSoundSpec>, ISoundReferenceSet, IDereferencer<String,IReferencedSoundSpec>, IItemReferenceIterable<IReferencedSoundSpec>, IShuffleIterable<IReferencedSoundSpec>, ISizedIterable<IReferencedSoundSpec>

    public class MetaData
extends AbstractSoundReferenceSet
implements ISoundReferenceSet
    Represents a CSV file of labels and tags to be applied to named sound files. Extends the super class to support reading/writing of the CSV file and to read the sound files. This class uses the file names with optional segment specification as the references to contained IReferencedSoundSpec objects.

    Format

    The metadata file is a CSV (comma separate value) file, named metadata.csv by default. It has the following format:
    • 3 columns with optional header and columns as described above.
      • Column 1 is the filename and optional segment specification
      • Column 2 is the semi-colon separated list of labels
      • Column 3 is the semi-colon separated list of tags
    An example might be the following: 
     sound1.wav,s1,source=engine;mic=built-in, 
 sound2.wav,s1,source=engine;mic=built-in,tag1=value1
 ...
 sound100.mp3,s2,source=cabin;mic=shotgun,tag2=value2;tag1=valueZ
 ...
    Segments are now specified with an optional set of square brackets specifying the start and end offsets of the segment in milliseconds. For example, 
     sound1.wav[1000-2000],s1,source=engine;mic=built-in, 
 ...
    Author:
    dawood

      • getFiles

        public Iterable<String> getFiles()
        Get the sound file referenced in the metadata file, in order as they appeared in the metadata file. Note that because some records may refer to the same file due to segmentation, the number of files may not be the same as the number of records in this instance.
        Returns:
        list of file names relative to this instance. Use getReferenceableFile(String) to turn the returned value into a path relative to the relative location of this instance.

      • getReferenceableFile

        public String getReferenceableFile(String fileOrReference)
        Get the path to a file listed in the metadata file using either file or a reference..
        Parameters:
        fileOrReference - file or reference. File values typically come from getFiles() and reference values from getReferences().
        Returns:
        if not an absolute path, then the file is assumed to be relative to this instance and the instance's location is prepended.

      • write

        public void write(String fileName,
                  boolean forLinux)
           throws IOException
        Write the instance to a comma-separated-value file.
        Parameters:
        fileName - the name of the file to write this instance to. If an absolute path, write the file there. If not an absolute path/file then the location is relative to that of this instance's location (per the constructor or read(String). In either case, if the file name represents a different location than is assigned to this instance, that is a move of the instance, then the filenames written to the resulting file will be absolute.
        forLinux - if true, then we remove leading 'x:' and change backslash (\) to forward slash (/).
        Throws:
        IOException
        See Also:
        #read(String)} for format produced.

      • write

        public void write(OutputStream stream,
                  boolean forLinux,
                  boolean absoluteSoundReferences)
           throws IOException
        Parameters:
        stream - not close on return.
        forLinux - remove : and change \ to / in sound file names.
        absoluteSoundReferences - use absolute paths when writing names of sound files.
        Throws:

      • writeMetaDataSounds

        public static List<String> writeMetaDataSounds(String dest,
                                               Iterable<SoundRecording> sounds)
                                        throws IOException
        A convenience over writeMetaDataSounds(String, Iterable, Iterable,boolean) in which no names are given so that only indexes are used to name the written sound files.
        Throws:
        IOException

      • writeMetaDataSounds

        public static List<String> writeMetaDataSounds(String dest,
                                               Iterable<SoundRecording> sounds,
                                               Iterable<String> fnames,
                                               boolean forLinux)
                                        throws IOException
        Write the given sounds and associated metadata file to the given directory. Sounds are written as WAV files with .wav extension. The names of the sounds are integer indexes, for example, 000001.wav unless names are provided.
        Parameters:
        dest - a directory or the name of a metadata file with a .csv extension. If the latter sounds are written to the directory specified. The directory must exist and if there is already a metadata file there, it is overwritten.
        sounds -
        fnames - names to be used to store the corresponding sounds. If null, empty or smaller than the iterable of sounds, then an incremented index is used to name the files. The iterable may contain null values in which case the corresponding sound will be saved in an indexed file name.
        writeSounds - if true then also write the given sounds using the optional names or indexed names if not provided.
        forLinux - if true then do not include '[X]:' from file name written into the metadata file.
        Returns:
        never null. the names of the files written into the dest directory.
        Throws:
        IOException

      • writeMetaDataSoundSegments

        public static List<String> writeMetaDataSoundSegments(String dest,
                                                      Iterable<SegmentedSoundRecording> sounds,
                                                      Iterable<String> fnames,
                                                      boolean forLinux)
                                               throws IOException
        Write the given segmented sounds and associated metadata file to the given directory. Sounds are written as WAV files with .wav extension. The names of the sounds are integer indexes, for example, 000001.wav unless names are provided. The resulting metadata file has one line for each segment, but multiple rows will generally refer to the same wav file when they segments of the same source sound. For example, 
         000001.wav[0-1000],...
 000001.wav[1000-2000],...
 000002.wav,...
 000003.wav[0-2000],...
 000003.wav[2000-3000],...
        If a SegmentedSoundRecording has now segments defined, the sound is treated as if the whole sound is one segment. Labels from segments are merged with those on the base SoundRecording. Same for tags.
        Parameters:
        dest - a directory or the name of a metadata file with a .csv extension. If the latter sounds are written to the directory specified. The directory must exist and if there is already a metadata file there, it is overwritten.
        sounds -
        fnames - names to be used to store the corresponding sounds. If null, empty or smaller than the iterable of sounds, then an incremented index is used to name the files. The iterable may contain null values in which case the corresponding sound will be saved in an indexed file name.
        writeSounds - if true then also write the given sounds using the optional names or indexed names if not provided.
        forLinux - if true then do not include '[X]:' from file name written into the metadata file.
        Returns:
        never null. the names of the files written into the dest directory.
        Throws:
        IOException - if failed to remove an existing metadata file or other errors writing either the wav or metadata file.

      • appendMetaDataSound

                                         SoundRecording sound)

      • newIterable

        public MetaData newIterable(Iterable<String> references)
        Description copied from class: AbstractReferenceShuffleIterable
        Override only to set the return type.
        Specified by:
        newIterable in interface IShuffleIterable<IReferencedSoundSpec>
        Parameters:
        references - the list of references to serve as a source for the iterable returned by IItemReferenceIterable.getReferences() of this instance and which ultimately produces the items from the iterable. Implementations are free to sub-select from the given list of references, but if they do then this sub-selection must be returned by the implementation's IItemReferenceIterable.getReferences() method.
        Returns:
        never null.

      • adjustAugmentedTags

        protected static SoundRecording adjustAugmentedTags(SoundRecording sr)
        Look for any special tags (or labels) and if found, a) then recreate a new recording based on them b) remove them in the modified recording.
        Parameters:
        sr - a recording that may containg special annotation tags (i.e. START_TIME_MSEC_LABEL, etc).
        Returns:
        never null. If not tags are found, then the given instance is returned.
        See Also:

      • sort

        public MetaData sort(MetaData sortBy)
        Create a new version of the this MetaData with its entries sorted by the order of references in the sortBy MetaData. Any entries in this instance not found in the sortBy instance, will not be included in the output MetaDAta.
        Parameters:
        sortBy - a metadata instance that contains matching IReferencedSound
        Returns:
        a new MetaData instance in the same location as the this instance, with entries ordered by those found in the sortBy MetaData

      • dereference

        public IReferencedSoundSpec dereference(String reference)
        Description copied from interface: IItemReferenceIterable
        Get the item(s) at the underlying reference.
        Parameters:
        reference - a reference string, presumably one that is a member of the iterable returned by IItemReferenceIterable.getReferences().
        Returns:
        null is supported but may trigger a NoSuchElementException elsewhere, such as IItemReferenceIterable.dereference(List).
